title: After I requested discovery by the Credit Card Collections attorney they sent me discovery forms?
question: This is nuts..I filed my response to the summons (credit card debt collections) then got a letter from the attorney asking me to make payments on a debt I don't know that I owe yet. I sent out discovery forms and I mean within 3 days I hade discovery forms sent to me! So I am not going to get the information I need before It is time for me to send back my answers to their discovery request. Something is not right here I don't think I have ever had a credit card by Chase and all I am asking for is proof that it is my debt. I suppose I keep saying defendant is without sufficient information until they give me what I am asking for? the way their questions are formed its like they are trying to get me to agree that I owe this money! any suggestions?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Criminal charges for identity theft,Police interrogation,Filing a lawsuit,Civil rights,Subpoena
answers:
Both sides have equal right to conduct written discovery and take depositions or subpoena documents and testimony from third parties, to prove their contentions in a lawsuit and hopefully either get factual and legal disputes resolved before trial or to prepare for trial presentation.

I have clients come to me after attempting to represent themselves and on the verge of or having been sanctioned for improperly responding to discovery from the opposing attorney. I have also seen people try to represent themselves, but without experience in civil litigation, they do not know how to resolve discovery disputes, when they (the self-represented person) sends out written discovery and either there is no response to it or the response are many objections and/or statements that are not on point to the written requests.

Your posting states that you never had a Chase credit card. If you did not open this account, then either it is a case of mistaken identity (someone else with the same name) or identity theft, for which you should get a police report for identity theft and follow the steps in my legal guide on Avvo (linked below) on what to do when you learn you are the victim of identity theft. You have numerous legal rights that you may not be asserting, if this was not your credit card. Failure to assert your rights often results in a waiver of such rights. Thus, you should retain experienced counsel right away.

Robert Stempler (see DISCLAIMER, below)
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com
You have to answer the discovery requests to the best of your ability or object to the questions.

Discovery is part of the litigation process & is limited by the court rules. Sometimes litigation can be brutal, but unless the discovery request goes beyond what is allowed in these court rules, you either comply or you will be penalized by the court.

Hope this perspective helps!

Although you may feel this is nuts, the plaintiff does have the right to conduct written discovery. It is quite common for the plaintiff to send you discovery responses, even if you did not send out yours. Don't assume the plaintiff was "retaliatory". Just answer each question truthfully by saying you have no knowledge nor information nor documents regarding this alleged debt.

You can always ask for a courtesy two-week extension of time to respond to their discovery, which should give you ample time to review their responses before you have to serve your responses.
